marstiming module¶

Mars timing information based on MARS24: http://www.giss.nasa.gov/tools/mars24/help/algorithm.html

Contains several functions for calculating Mars time parameters from Earth time and vice versa. Probably the most useful functions are: getMTfromTime: gets mars time data given a 6 element time list getSZAfromTime: gets the SZA from a 6 element time list and coordinates getLTfromTime: gets the LTST from a 6 element time list and longitude getUTCfromLS: Estimates the Earth time from LS and a Mars year

marstiming.getJ2000(iTime)[source]¶

get offset from J2000 epoch.

marstiming.getJD(iTime)[source]¶

Get the Julian date in seconds

marstiming.getLTfromTime(iTime, lon)[source]¶

The mars local solar time from an earth time and mars longitude.

Parameters:
  • iTime – 6 element list: [y,m,d,h,m,s]
  • lon – the longitude in degrees
Returns:

The local time (float)
marstiming.getMTfromTime(iTime)[source]¶

Get Mars time information.

Parameters:iTime – 6 element time list [y,m,d,h,m,s]
Returns:a named tuple containing the LS value as well as several parameters necessary for other calculations
marstiming.getMarsParams(j2000)[source]¶

Mars time parameters

marstiming.getSZAfromTime(iTime, lon, lat)[source]¶

Get SZA from Earth time and Mars coordinates.

Parameters:
  • a 6 element list (iTime) – [y,m,d,h,m,s]
  • lon – the longitude in degrees
  • lat – the latitude in degrees
Returns:

the solar zenith angle (float)
marstiming.getUTC(jd)[source]¶

Get UTC given jd

marstiming.getUTCfromLS(marsyear, LS)[source]¶

Get a UTC starting with an estimate of LS using an orbit angle approximation then iteratively closing in on the correct LS by incrementing the a day first and then hour.

Parameters:
  • marsyear – an int mars year
  • ls – ls- mars solar longitude
Returns:

UTC1 (python datetime)
marstiming.mapSZA(iTime)[source]¶

Create an SZA map given an Earth time

Parameters:iTime – 6 element list: [y,m,d,h,m,s]
Returns:null
